number of counters accessed.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.9361,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"8d8f4284\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"8d8f4284-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/compare-data-types.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Compare data types\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Data type features\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis provides a wide range of data types to store your data.\\\\nThe following are highly specialized for precise purposes:\\\\n\\\\n-   [Geospatial]():\\\\n    store strings with associated coordinates for geospatial queries.\\\\n-   [Vector sets]():\\\\n    store strings with associated vector data (and optional metadata)\\\\n    for vector similarity queries.\\\\n-   [Probabilistic data types]():\\\\n    keep approximate counts and other statistics for large datasets.\\\\n-   [Time series]():\\\\n    store real-valued data points along with the time they were collected.\\\\n\\\\nThe remaining data types are more general-purpose:\\\\n\\\\n-   [Strings]():\\\\n    store text or binary data.\\\\n-   [Hashes]():\\\\n    store key-value pairs within a single key.\\\\n-   [JSON]():\\\\n    store structured, hierarchical arrays and key-value objects that match\\\\n    the popular [JSON](https://www.json.org/json-en.html) text file format.\\\\n-   [Lists]():\\\\n    store a simple sequence of strings.\\\\n-   [Sets]():\\\\n    store a collection of unique strings.\\\\n-   [Sorted sets]():\\\\n    store a collection of unique strings with associated scores.\\\\n-   [Streams]():\\\\n    store a sequence of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs.\\\\n\\\\nThe general-purpose data types have some overlap among their features\\\\nand indeed, you could probably emulate any of them using just strings\\\\nand a little creativity. However, each data type provides different\\\\ntradeoffs in terms of performance, memory usage, and functionality.\\\\nThis guide helps you choose the best data type for your task.\\\\n\\\\nThe sections below summarize the features of each data type.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.1267,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"43b5f91b\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"43b5f91b-007\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis lists\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Learn more\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"So far in our examples we never had to create empty lists before pushing\\\\nelements, or removing empty lists when they no longer have elements inside.\\\\nIt is Redis\' responsibility to delete keys when lists are left empty, or to create\\\\nan empty list if the key does not exist and we are trying to add elements\\\\nto it, for example, with [`LPUSH`]().\\\\n\\\\nThis is not specific to lists, it applies to all the Redis data types\\\\ncomposed of multiple elements -- Streams, Sets, Sorted Sets and Hashes.\\\\n\\\\nBasically we can summarize the behavior with three rules:\\\\n\\\\n1. When we add an element to an aggregate data type, if the target key does not exist, an empty aggregate data type is created before adding the element.\\\\n2. When we remove elements from an aggregate data type, if the value remains empty, the key is automatically destroyed. The Stream data type is the only exception to this rule.\\\\n3. Calling a read-only command such as [`LLEN`]() (which returns the length of the list), or a write command removing elements, with an empty key, always produces the same result as if the key is holding an empty aggregate type of the type the command expects to find.\\\\n\\\\nExamples of rule 1:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL new_bikes\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n> LPUSH new_bikes bike:1 bike:2 bike:3\\\\n(integer) 3\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nHowever we can\'t perform operations against the wrong type if the key exists:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL new_bikes\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SET new_bikes bike:1\\\\nOK\\\\n> TYPE new_bikes\\\\nstring\\\\n> LPUSH new_bikes bike:2 bike:3\\\\n(error) WRONGTYPE Operation against a key holding the wrong kind of value\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nExample of rule 2:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3\\\\n(integer) 3\\\\n> EXISTS bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> LPOP bikes:repairs\\\\n\\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n> LPOP bikes:repairs\\\\n\\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n> LPOP bikes:repairs\\\\n\\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n> EXISTS bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe key no longer exists after all the elements are popped.\\\\n\\\\nExample of rule 3:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n> LLEN bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n> LPOP bikes:repairs\\\\n(nil)\\\\n\\\\nThe maximum length of a Redis list is 2^32 - 1 (4,294,967,295) elements.\\\\n\\\\nList operations that access its head or tail are O(1), which means they\'re highly efficient.\\\\nHowever, commands that manipulate elements within a list are usually O(n).\\\\nExamples of these include [`LINDEX`](), [`LINSERT`](), and [`LSET`]().\\\\nExercise caution when running these commands, mainly when operating on large lists.\\\\n\\\\nConsider [Redis streams]() as an alternative to lists when you need to store and process an indeterminate series of events.\\\\n\\\\n* [Redis Lists Explained](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PB5SeOkkxQc) is a short, comprehensive video explainer on Redis lists.\\\\n* [Redis University\'s RU101](https://university.redis.com/courses/ru101/) covers Redis lists in detail.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.9406,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"1a112c0f\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1a112c0f-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/get-started/faq.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis FAQ\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Why does Redis keep its entire dataset in memory?\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"* Redis has a different evolution path in the key-value DBs where values can contain more complex data types, with atomic operations defined on those data types. Redis data types are closely related to fundamental data structures and are exposed to the programmer as such, without additional abstraction layers.\\\\n* Redis is an in-memory but persistent on disk database, so it represents a different trade off where very high write and read speed is achieved with the limitation of data sets that can\'t be larger than memory. Another advantage of\\\\nin-memory databases is that the memory representation of complex data structures\\\\nis much simpler to manipulate compared to the same data structures on disk, so\\\\nRedis can do a lot with little internal complexity. At the same time the\\\\ntwo on-disk storage formats (RDB and AOF) don\'t need to be suitable for random\\\\naccess, so they are compact and always generated in an append-only fashion\\\\n(Even the AOF log rotation is an append-only operation, since the new version\\\\nis generated from the copy of data in memory). However this design also involves\\\\ndifferent challenges compared to traditional on-disk stores. Being the main data\\\\nrepresentation on memory, Redis operations must be carefully handled to make sure\\\\nthere is always an updated version of the data set on disk.\\\\n\\\\nTo give you a few examples (all obtained using 64-bit instances):\\\\n\\\\n* An empty instance uses ~ 3MB of memory.\\\\n* 1 Million small Keys -> String Value pairs use ~ 85MB of memory.\\\\n* 1 Million Keys -> Hash value, representing an object with 5 fields, use ~ 160 MB of memory.\\\\n\\\\nTesting your use case is trivial. Use the `redis-benchmark` utility to generate random data sets then check the space used with the `INFO memory` command.\\\\n\\\\n64-bit systems will use considerably more memory than 32-bit systems to store the same keys, especially if the keys and values are small. This is because pointers take 8 bytes in 64-bit systems. But of course the advantage is that you can\\\\nhave a lot of memory in 64-bit systems, so in order to run large Redis servers a 64-bit system is more or less required. The alternative is sharding.\\\\n\\\\nIn the past the Redis developers experimented with Virtual Memory and other systems in order to allow larger than RAM datasets, but after all we are very happy if we can do one thing well: data served from memory, disk used for storage. So for now there are no plans to create an on disk backend for Redis. Most of what\\\\nRedis is, after all, a direct result of its current design.\\\\n\\\\nIf your real problem is not the total RAM needed, but the fact that you need\\\\nto split your data set into multiple Redis instances, please read the\\\\n[partitioning page]() in this documentation for more info.\\\\n\\\\nRedis Ltd., the company sponsoring Redis development, has developed a\\\\n\\\\\\"Redis on Flash\\\\\\" solution that uses a mixed RAM/flash approach for\\\\nlarger data sets with a biased access pattern. You may check their offering\\\\nfor more information, however this feature is not part of the Redis Open Source\\\\ncode base.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.747,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"b7e8b170\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"b7e8b170-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Memory optimization\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Use hashes when possible\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"When Redis is compiled as a 32-bit target, it uses a lot less memory per key, since pointers are small,\\\\nbut such an instance will be limited to 4 GB of maximum memory usage.\\\\nTo compile Redis as 32-bit binary use *make 32bit*.\\\\nRDB and AOF files are compatible between 32-bit and 64-bit instances\\\\n(and between little and big endian of course) so you can switch from 32 to 64-bit, or the contrary, without problems.\\\\n\\\\nRedis 2.2 introduced new bit and byte level operations: [`GETRANGE`](/commands/getrange), [`SETRANGE`](/commands/setrange), [`GETBIT`](/commands/getbit) and [`SETBIT`](/commands/setbit).\\\\nUsing these commands you can treat the Redis string type as a random access array.\\\\nFor instance, if you have an application where users are identified by a unique progressive integer number,\\\\nyou can use a bitmap to save information about the subscription of users in a mailing list,\\\\nsetting the bit for subscribed and clearing it for unsubscribed, or the other way around.\\\\nWith 100 million users this data will take just 12 megabytes of RAM in a Redis instance.\\\\nYou can do the same using [`GETRANGE`](/commands/getrange) and [`SETRANGE`](/commands/setrange) to store one byte of information for each user.\\\\nThis is just an example but it is possible to model several problems in very little space with these new primitives.\\\\n\\\\nSmall hashes are encoded in a very small space, so you should try representing your data using hashes whenever possible.\\\\nFor instance, if you have objects representing users in a web application, \\\\ninstead of using different keys for name, surname, email, password, use a single hash with all the required fields.\\\\n\\\\nIf you want to know more about this, read the next section.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='## Redis Bitfields

Redis Bitfields let you set, increment, and get integer values of arbitrary bit length. You can operate on anything from unsigned 1-bit integers to signed 63-bit integers.

**Key characteristics:**
- Values are stored using binary-encoded Redis strings
- Support atomic read, write, and increment operations
- Good choice for managing counters and similar numerical values

**Main commands:**
- `BITFIELD` - atomically sets, increments, and reads one or more values
- `BITFIELD_RO` - read-only variant of BITFIELD

**When to use them:**

Bitfields are ideal when you need to:
1. **Store multiple counters efficiently** - Pack multiple integer values into a single Redis key
2. **Manage metrics with different ranges** - Each counter can have its own bit width (e.g., 32-bit for prices, 16-bit for counts)
3. **Perform atomic updates** - Update multiple counters in a single atomic operation

**Example use case:**

Tracking bicycle statistics (price and number of owners):

```redis
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats SET u32 #0 1000
1) (integer) 0

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 -50 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 950
2) (integer) 1

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 500 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats GET u32 #0 GET u32 #1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2
```

In this example, offset #0 stores the price (32-bit unsigned) and offset #1 stores the owner count, both packed into a single key.

**Performance:** `BITFIELD` is O(n), where n is the number of counters accessed.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/bitfields.md > Performance]')]

## Redis Bitfields

Redis Bitfields let you set, increment, and get integer values of arbitrary bit length. You can operate on anything from unsigned 1-bit integers to signed 63-bit integers.

**Key characteristics:**
- Values are stored using binary-encoded Redis strings
- Support atomic read, write, and increment operations
- Good choice for managing counters and similar numerical values

**Main commands:**
- `BITFIELD` - atomically sets, increments, and reads one or more values
- `BITFIELD_RO` - read-only variant of BITFIELD

**When to use them:**

Bitfields are ideal when you need to:
1. **Store multiple counters efficiently** - Pack multiple integer values into a single Redis key
2. **Manage metrics with different ranges** - Each counter can have its own bit width (e.g., 32-bit for prices, 16-bit for counts)
3. **Perform atomic updates** - Update multiple counters in a single atomic operation

**Example use case:**

Tracking bicycle statistics (price and number of owners):

```redis
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats SET u32 #0 1000
1) (integer) 0

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 -50 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 950
2) (integer) 1

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 500 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats GET u32 #0 GET u32 #1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2
```

In this example, offset #0 stores the price (32-bit unsigned) and offset #1 stores the owner count, both packed into a single key.

**Performance:** `BITFIELD` is O(n), where n is the number of counters accessed.

query: How to store and query geospatial data in Redis?
answer:
Redis provides geospatial indexes for storing and querying location-based data. Here's how to work with geospatial data:

## Storing Geospatial Data

Use the `GEOADD` command to add locations with their coordinates (longitude, latitude):

```redis
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.27652 37.805186 station:1
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2674626 37.8062344 station:2
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2469854 37.8104049 station:3
```

**Note:** Longitude comes before latitude in the command.

## Querying Geospatial Data

Use `GEOSEARCH` to find locations within a radius or bounding box:

```redis
GEOSEARCH bikes:rentable FROMLONLAT -122.2612767 37.7936847 BYRADIUS 5 km WITHDIST
```

This returns all stations within 5 km of the given coordinates, along with their distances:

```
1) 1) "station:1"
   2) "1.8523"
2) 1) "station:2"
   2) "1.4979"
3) 1) "station:3"
   2) "2.2441"
```

## Use Cases

Geospatial indexes are ideal for:
- Finding nearby points within a given radius
- Location-based searches (e.g., bike rental stations, restaurants, stores)
- Proximity queries with distance calculations

## Important Note

The Geospatial data type is designed for simpler use cases. For more advanced geospatial features with additional format options and query capabilities, consider using Redis Query Engine's geospatial features.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/geospatial.md > Learn more]

query: Redis TimeSeries 适合什么场景？怎么配置 retention？
answer:
## Redis TimeSeries 适合什么场景？

Redis TimeSeries 适用于需要处理时间序列数据的多种场景：

### 1. 监控与运维
- **数据中心监控**：服务器 CPU 利用率、网络延迟、存储 IO 带宽、应用响应时间（如 99th percentile）
- **根因分析**：重建导致故障的事件序列

### 2. 环境与气象
- **天气分析**：降雨量、温度、日照时长的长期追踪和季节性分析
- **大气监测**：CO2 浓度的历史趋势分析

### 3. 物联网与传感器数据
- **飞行数据记录**：高度、航迹、引擎温度、振动、压力等黑匣子数据
- **船舶日志**：风速、海况、航速、位置
- **车联网**：油耗、轮胎压力、位置、速度、保养里程
- **智能电表**：能源消耗/生产数据的实时采集和账单聚合

### 4. 金融与电信
- **股票交易**：毫秒级价格波动、交易量、异常检测
- **电信 QoS**：基站流量监控、负载均衡、容量规划

### 5. 核心优势
- **标签索引**：通过 field-value 标签（如 `sensor_id`, `area_id`）快速过滤和查询相关时间序列
- **降采样**：支持 avg/sum/min/max/range/count/first/last 聚合，减少历史数据存储
- **集成生态**：原生支持 Prometheus、Grafana

---

## 如何配置 retention（数据保留时间）？

Redis TimeSeries 的 retention 配置有**三级优先级**：

### 1. Key 级别（最高优先级）
创建或修改时间序列时指定：

```sh
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

```sh
TS.ALTER temperature RETENTION 86400000
```

单位：毫秒（60000 = 60 秒）

### 2. 全局默认配置（中优先级）

**Redis < 8.0**（启动时加载）：
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

**Redis >= 8.0**（运行时配置）：
```bash
CONFIG SET ts-retention-policy 25920000000
CONFIG REWRITE  # 持久化到配置文件
```

示例：25920000000 毫秒 = 300 天

### 3. 无保留策略（最低优先级）
如果未设置任何 retention，数据将无限期保留。

### 配置建议
- 对于监控场景，根据数据重要性分级设置（如原始数据 7 天，聚合数据 1 年）
- 结合降采样（downsampling）减少长期存储成本
- 在集群环境中，需在每个节点单独执行 `CONFIG SET`

---

**来源**：
- [Redis TimeSeries Configuration Parameters](../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md) > RETENTION_POLICY 配置示例
- [Redis TimeSeries Use Cases](../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md) > 场景详解
- [RedisTimeSeries 1.0 Release Notes](../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md) > Features 章节

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_Ay02YTHz1TjVePZcmcUJcD', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.6635,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6072bd82\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6072bd82-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redistimeseries 1.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features > Integrations\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"If you want to keep all of your raw data points indefinitely, your data set will grow linearly over time. However, if your use case allows you to have less fine-grained data further back in time, downsampling can be applied. This allows you to keep fewer historical data points by aggregating raw data for a given time window using a given aggregation function. RedisTimeSeries supports downsampling with the following aggregations: avg, sum, min, max, range, count, first and last.\\\\n\\\\nWhen using Redis’ core data structures, you can only retrieve a time series by knowing the exact key holding the time series. Unfortunately, for many time series use cases (such as root cause analysis or monitoring), your application won’t know the exact key it’s looking for. These use cases typically want to query a set of time series that relate to each other in a couple of dimensions to extract the insight you need. You could create your own secondary index with core Redis data structures to help with this, but it would come with a high development cost and require you to manage edge cases to make sure the index is correct.\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries does this indexing for you based on `field value` pairs (a.k.a labels) you can add to each time series, and use to filter at query time (a full list of these filters is available in our documentation). Here’s an example of creating a time series with two labels (sensor_id and area_id are the fields with values 2 and 32 respectively) and a retention window of 60,000 milliseconds:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\nTS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWhen you need to query a time series, it’s cumbersome to stream all raw data points if you’re only interested in, say, an average over a given time interval. RedisTimeSeries follows the Redis philosophy to only transfer the minimum required data to ensure lowest latency. Below is an example of aggregation query over time buckets of 5,000 milliseconds with an aggregation function:  \\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> TS.RANGE temperature:3:32 1548149180000 1548149210000 AGGREGATION avg 5000\\\\n1) 1) (integer) 1548149180000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"26.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n2) 1) (integer) 1548149185000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"27.399999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n3) 1) (integer) 1548149190000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"24.800000000000001\\\\\\"\\\\n4) 1) (integer) 1548149195000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"23.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n5) 1) (integer) 1548149200000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"25.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n6) 1) (integer) 1548149205000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"28\\\\\\"\\\\n7) 1) (integer) 1548149210000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"20\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries comes with several integrations into existing time series tools. One such integration is our [RedisTimeSeries adapter for Prometheus](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-redistimeseries-adapter), which keeps all your monitoring metrics inside RedisTimeSeries while leveraging the entire Prometheus ecosystem.\\\\nFurthermore, we also created direct integration for [Grafana](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/grafana-redistimeseries). [This repository](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-demos) contains a docker-compose setup of RedisTimeSeries, its remote write adaptor, Prometheus and Grafana. It also comes with a set of data generators and pre-built Grafana dashboards.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.2897,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"1bdc4c21\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1bdc4c21-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/latency-monitor.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis latency monitoring\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis is often used for demanding use cases, where it\\\\nserves a large number of queries per second per instance, but also has strict latency requirements for the average response\\\\ntime and the worst-case latency.\\\\n\\\\nWhile Redis is an in-memory system, it deals with the operating system in\\\\ndifferent ways, for example, in the context of persisting to disk.\\\\nMoreover Redis implements a rich set of commands. Certain commands\\\\nare fast and run in constant or logarithmic time. Other commands are slower\\\\nO(N) commands that can cause latency spikes.\\\\n\\\\nFinally, Redis is single threaded. This is usually an advantage\\\\nfrom the point of view of the amount of work it can perform per core, and in\\\\nthe latency figures it is able to provide. However, it poses\\\\na challenge for latency, since the single\\\\nthread must be able to perform certain tasks incrementally, for\\\\nexample key expiration, in a way that does not impact the other clients\\\\nthat are served.\\\\n\\\\nFor all these reasons, Redis 2.8.13 introduced a new feature called\\\\n**Latency Monitoring**, that helps the user to check and troubleshoot possible\\\\nlatency problems. Latency monitoring is composed of the following conceptual\\\\nparts:\\\\n\\\\n* Latency hooks that sample different latency-sensitive code paths.\\\\n* Time series recording of latency spikes, split by different events.\\\\n* Reporting engine to fetch raw data from the time series.\\\\n* Analysis engine to provide human-readable reports and hints according to the measurements.\\\\n\\\\nThe rest of this document covers the latency monitoring subsystem\\\\ndetails. For more information about the general topic of Redis\\\\nand latency, see [Redis latency problems troubleshooting]().\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.4797,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"43b5f91b\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"43b5f91b-005\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis lists\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Examples > Capped lists\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Lists are useful for a number of tasks, two very representative use cases\\\\nare the following:\\\\n\\\\n* Remember the latest updates posted by users into a social network.\\\\n* Communication between processes, using a consumer-producer pattern where the producer pushes items into a list, and a consumer (usually a *worker*) consumes those items and executes actions. Redis has special list commands to make this use case both more reliable and efficient.\\\\n\\\\nFor example both the popular Ruby libraries [resque](https://github.com/resque/resque) and\\\\n[sidekiq](https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq) use Redis lists under the hood in order to\\\\nimplement background jobs.\\\\n\\\\nThe popular Twitter social network [takes the latest tweets](http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Real-Time-Delivery-Twitter)\\\\nposted by users into Redis lists.\\\\n\\\\nTo describe a common use case step by step, imagine your home page shows the latest\\\\nphotos published in a photo sharing social network and you want to speedup access.\\\\n\\\\n* Every time a user posts a new photo, we add its ID into a list with [`LPUSH`]().\\\\n* When users visit the home page, we use `LRANGE 0 9` in order to get the latest 10 posted items.\\\\n\\\\nIn many use cases we just want to use lists to store the *latest items*,\\\\nwhatever they are: social network updates, logs, or anything else.\\\\n\\\\nRedis allows us to use lists as a capped collection, only remembering the latest\\\\nN items and discarding all the oldest items using the [`LTRIM`]() command.\\\\n\\\\nThe [`LTRIM`]() command is similar to [`LRANGE`](), but **instead of displaying the\\\\nspecified range of elements** it sets this range as the new list value. All\\\\nthe elements outside the given range are removed.\\\\n\\\\nFor example, if you\'re adding bikes on the end of a list of repairs, but only\\\\nwant to worry about the 3 that have been on the list the longest:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> LTRIM bikes:repairs 0 2\\\\nOK\\\\n> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe above [`LTRIM`]() command tells Redis to keep just list elements from index\\\\n0 to 2, everything else will be discarded. This allows for a very simple but\\\\nuseful pattern: doing a List push operation + a List trim operation together \\\\nto add a new element and discard elements exceeding a limit. Using \\\\n[`LTRIM`]() with negative indexes can then be used to keep only the 3 most recently added:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> LTRIM bikes:repairs -3 -1\\\\nOK\\\\n> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:4\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:5\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe above combination adds new elements and keeps only the 3\\\\nnewest elements into the list. With [`LRANGE`]() you can access the top items\\\\nwithout any need to remember very old data.\\\\n\\\\nNote: while [`LRANGE`]() is technically an O(N) command, accessing small ranges\\\\ntowards the head or the tail of the list is a constant time operation.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.434,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6072bd82\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6072bd82-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redistimeseries 1.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"In RedisTimeSeries, we are introducing a new data type that uses chunks of memory of fixed size for time series samples, indexed by the same [Radix Tree implementation](https://github.com/antirez/rax) as Redis Streams. With Streams, you can create a [capped stream](, effectively limiting the number of messages by count. In RedisTimeSeries, you can apply a retention policy in milliseconds. This is better for time series use cases, because they are typically interested in the data during a given time window, rather than a fixed number of samples.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.4249,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"7b673af6\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7b673af6-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Use cases\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"**Monitoring (data center)**\\\\n\\\\nModern data centers have a lot of moving pieces, such as infrastructure (servers and networks) and software systems (applications and services) that need to be monitored around the clock.\\\\n\\\\nRedis Time Series allows you to plan for new resources upfront, optimize the utilization of existing resources, reconstruct the circumstances that led to outages, and identify application performance issues by analyzing and reporting on the following metrics:\\\\n\\\\n- Maximum CPU utilization per server\\\\n- Maximum network latency between two services\\\\n- Average IO bandwidth utilization of a storage system\\\\n- 99th percentile of the response time of a specific application outages\\\\n\\\\n**Weather analysis (environment)**\\\\n\\\\nRedis Time Series can be used to track environmental measurements such as the number of daily sunshine hours and hourly rainfall depth, over a period of many years. Seasonally, you can measure average rainfall depth, average daily temperature, and the maximum number of sunny hours per day, for example. Watch the increase of the maximum daily temperature over the years. Predict the expected temperature and rainfall depth in a specific location for a particular week of the year.\\\\n\\\\nMultiple time series can be collected, each for a different location. By utilizing secondary indexes, measurements can be aggregated over given geographical regions (e.g., minimal and maximal daily temperature in Europe) or over locations with specific attributes (e.g., average rainfall depth in mountainous regions).\\\\n\\\\nExample metrics include: \\\\n\\\\n- Rain (cm)\\\\n- Temperature (C)\\\\n- Sunny periods (h)\\\\n\\\\n**Analysis of the atmosphere (environment)**\\\\n\\\\nThe atmospheric concentration of CO2 is more important than ever before. Use TimeSeries to track average, maximum and minimum CO2 level per season and average yearly CO2 over the last decades. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Concentration of CO2 (ppm)\\\\n- Location\\\\n\\\\n**Flight data recording (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nPlanes have a multitude of sensors. This sensor data is stored in a black box and also shared with external systems. TimeSeries can help you reconstruct the sequence of events over time, optimize operations and maintenance intervals, improve safety, and provide feedback to the equipment manufacturers about the part quality. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Altitude\\\\n- Flight path\\\\n- Engine temperature\\\\n- Level of vibrations\\\\n- Pressure\\\\n\\\\n**Ship logbooks (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nIt\'s very common to keep track of ship voyages via (digital) logbooks. Use TimeSeries to calculate optimal routes using these metrics:\\\\n\\\\n- Wind (km/h)\\\\n- Ocean conditions (classes)\\\\n- Speed (knots)\\\\n- Location (long, lat)\\\\n\\\\n**Connected car (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nModern cars are exposing several metrics via a standard interface. Use TimeSeries to correlate average fuel consumption with the tire pressure, figure out how long to keep a car in the fleet, determine optimal maintenance intervals, and calculate tax savings by type of the road (taxable vs. nontaxable roads). Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Acceleration\\\\n- Location (long, lat)\\\\n- Fuel level (liter)\\\\n- Distances (km)\\\\n- Speed (km/h)\\\\n- Tire pressure\\\\n- Distance until next maintenance check\\\\n\\\\n**Smart metering (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nModern houses and facilities gather details about energy consumption/production. Use Redis Time Series to aggregate billing based on monthly consumption. Optimize the network by redirecting the energy delivery relative to the fluctuations in need. Provide recommendations on how to improve the energy consumption behavior. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Consumption per location\\\\n- Produced amount of electrical energy per location\\\\n\\\\n**Quality of service (telecom)**\\\\n\\\\nMobile phone usage is increasing, producing a natural growth that just correlates to the increasing number of cellphones. However, there might also be spikes that correlate with specific events (for example, more messages around world championships). \\\\n\\\\nTelecom providers need to ensure that they are providing the necessary infrastructure to deliver the right quality of service. This includes using mini towers for short-term peaks. Use TimeSeries to correlate traffic peaks to specific events, load balance traffic over several towers or mini towers, and predictively plan the infrastructure. Metrics include the amount of traffic per tower.\\\\n\\\\n**Stock trading (finance)**\\\\n\\\\nStock trading is highly automated today. Algorithms, and not just human beings, are trading, from the amount of bids and asks for the trading of a stock to the extreme volumes of trades per second (millions of ops per second). Computer-driven trading requires millisecond response times. It\'s necessary to keep a lot of data points within a very short period of time (for example, price fluctuations per second within a minute). In addition, the long-term history needs to be kept to make statements about trends or for regulatory purposes.  \\\\n\\\\nUse Redis Time Series to identify correlations between the trading behavior and other events (for example, social network posts). Discover a developing market. Detect anomalies to discover insider trades. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Exact time and order of a trade by itself\\\\n- Type of the event (trade/bid)\\\\n- The stock price\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

Click **Save**.\\\\n\\\\n[Redis Cloud]() does not let you configure RedisTimeSeries manually. However, if you have a Flexible or Annual [subscription](), you can contact [support](https://redis.com/company/support/) to request a configuration change. You cannot change RedisTimeSeries configuration for Free or Fixed subscriptions.\\\\n\\\\nSee [configuration parameters]() in the Develop section for parameter details and compatibility with Redis Software and Redis Cloud.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.0187,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6072bd82\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6072bd82-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redistimeseries 1.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features > Integrations\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"If you want to keep all of your raw data points indefinitely, your data set will grow linearly over time. However, if your use case allows you to have less fine-grained data further back in time, downsampling can be applied. This allows you to keep fewer historical data points by aggregating raw data for a given time window using a given aggregation function. RedisTimeSeries supports downsampling with the following aggregations: avg, sum, min, max, range, count, first and last.\\\\n\\\\nWhen using Redis’ core data structures, you can only retrieve a time series by knowing the exact key holding the time series. RedisTimeSeries follows the Redis philosophy to only transfer the minimum required data to ensure lowest latency. Below is an example of aggregation query over time buckets of 5,000 milliseconds with an aggregation function:  \\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> TS.RANGE temperature:3:32 1548149180000 1548149210000 AGGREGATION avg 5000\\\\n1) 1) (integer) 1548149180000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"26.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n2) 1) (integer) 1548149185000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"27.399999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n3) 1) (integer) 1548149190000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"24.800000000000001\\\\\\"\\\\n4) 1) (integer) 1548149195000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"23.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n5) 1) (integer) 1548149200000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"25.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n6) 1) (integer) 1548149205000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"28\\\\\\"\\\\n7) 1) (integer) 1548149210000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"20\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries comes with several integrations into existing time series tools. One such integration is our [RedisTimeSeries adapter for Prometheus](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-redistimeseries-adapter), which keeps all your monitoring metrics inside RedisTimeSeries while leveraging the entire Prometheus ecosystem.\\\\nFurthermore, we also created direct integration for [Grafana](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/grafana-redistimeseries). [This repository](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-demos) contains a docker-compose setup of RedisTimeSeries, its remote write adaptor, Prometheus and Grafana. It also comes with a set of data generators and pre-built Grafana dashboards.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.4311,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"608370db\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"608370db-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Configuration Parameters\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Open Source - set configuration parameters\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Before Redis 8 in Redis Open Source (version 8.0), all time series configuration parameters are load-time parameters.\\\\nUse one of the following methods to set the values of load-time configuration parameters:\\\\n\\\\n- Pass them as command-line arguments following the `loadmodule` argument when starting `redis-server`:\\\\n\\\\n  `redis-server --loadmodule ./{modulename}.so [OPT VAL]...`\\\\n\\\\n- Add them as arguments to the `loadmodule` directive in your configuration file (for example, `redis.conf`):\\\\n\\\\n  `loadmodule ./{modulename}.so [OPT VAL]...`\\\\n\\\\n- Use the `MODULE LOAD path [arg [arg ...]]` command.\\\\n\\\\n- Use the `MODULE LOADEX path [CONFIG name value [CONFIG name value ...]] [ARGS args [args ....]]` command.\\\\n\\\\nStarting with Redis 8.0, most time series configuration parameters are runtime parameters.\\\\nWhile you can set runtime parameters at load time, using the Redis `CONFIG` command is easier and works the same way as with Redis runtime configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\nThis means:\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG SET parameter value [parameter value ...] `\\\\n\\\\n  Set one or more configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG GET parameter [parameter ...]`\\\\n\\\\n  Read the current value of one of more parameters.\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG REWRITE`\\\\n\\\\n  Rewrite your Redis configuration file (for example, the `redis.conf` file) to reflect the configuration changes.\\\\n\\\\nStarting with Redis 8.0, you can specify time series configuration parameters directly in your Redis configuration file the same way you would for Redis configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\nOnce a value is set with `CONFIG SET` or added manually to your configuration file, it will overwrite values set with `--loadmodule`, `loadmodule`, `MODULE LOAD`, or `MODULE LOADEX`.\\\\n\\\\nIn a cluster, you must run `CONFIG SET` and `CONFIG REWRITE` on each node separately.\\\\n\\\\nIn Redis 8.0, new names for the time series configuration parameters were introduced to align the naming with the Redis configuration parameters.\\\\nYou must use the new names when using the `CONFIG` command.\\\\n\\\\nSee also [Redis configuration]().\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='## Redis TimeSeries 适合什么场景？

Redis TimeSeries 适用于需要处理时间序列数据的多种场景：

### 1. 监控与运维
- **数据中心监控**：服务器 CPU 利用率、网络延迟、存储 IO 带宽、应用响应时间（如 99th percentile）
- **根因分析**：重建导致故障的事件序列

### 2. 环境与气象
- **天气分析**：降雨量、温度、日照时长的长期追踪和季节性分析
- **大气监测**：CO2 浓度的历史趋势分析

### 3. 物联网与传感器数据
- **飞行数据记录**：高度、航迹、引擎温度、振动、压力等黑匣子数据
- **船舶日志**：风速、海况、航速、位置
- **车联网**：油耗、轮胎压力、位置、速度、保养里程
- **智能电表**：能源消耗/生产数据的实时采集和账单聚合

### 4. 金融与电信
- **股票交易**：毫秒级价格波动、交易量、异常检测
- **电信 QoS**：基站流量监控、负载均衡、容量规划

### 5. 核心优势
- **标签索引**：通过 field-value 标签（如 `sensor_id`, `area_id`）快速过滤和查询相关时间序列
- **降采样**：支持 avg/sum/min/max/range/count/first/last 聚合，减少历史数据存储
- **集成生态**：原生支持 Prometheus、Grafana

---

## 如何配置 retention（数据保留时间）？

Redis TimeSeries 的 retention 配置有**三级优先级**：

### 1. Key 级别（最高优先级）
创建或修改时间序列时指定：

```sh
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

```sh
TS.ALTER temperature RETENTION 86400000
```

单位：毫秒（60000 = 60 秒）

### 2. 全局默认配置（中优先级）

**Redis < 8.0**（启动时加载）：
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

**Redis >= 8.0**（运行时配置）：
```bash
CONFIG SET ts-retention-policy 25920000000
CONFIG REWRITE  # 持久化到配置文件
```

示例：25920000000 毫秒 = 300 天

### 3. 无保留策略（最低优先级）
如果未设置任何 retention，数据将无限期保留。

### 配置建议
- 对于监控场景，根据数据重要性分级设置（如原始数据 7 天，聚合数据 1 年）
- 结合降采样（downsampling）减少长期存储成本
- 在集群环境中，需在每个节点单独执行 `CONFIG SET`

---

**来源**：

- [Redis TimeSeries Use Cases](../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md) > 场景详解
- [RedisTimeSeries 1.0 Release Notes](../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md) > Features 章节')]

messages.result:
## Redis TimeSeries 适合什么场景？

Redis TimeSeries 适用于需要处理时间序列数据的多种场景：

### 1. 监控与运维
- **数据中心监控**：服务器 CPU 利用率、网络延迟、存储 IO 带宽、应用响应时间（如 99th percentile）
- **根因分析**：重建导致故障的事件序列

### 2. 环境与气象
- **天气分析**：降雨量、温度、日照时长的长期追踪和季节性分析
- **大气监测**：CO2 浓度的历史趋势分析

### 3. 物联网与传感器数据
- **飞行数据记录**：高度、航迹、引擎温度、振动、压力等黑匣子数据
- **船舶日志**：风速、海况、航速、位置
- **车联网**：油耗、轮胎压力、位置、速度、保养里程
- **智能电表**：能源消耗/生产数据的实时采集和账单聚合

### 4. 金融与电信
- **股票交易**：毫秒级价格波动、交易量、异常检测
- **电信 QoS**：基站流量监控、负载均衡、容量规划

### 5. 核心优势
- **标签索引**：通过 field-value 标签（如 `sensor_id`, `area_id`）快速过滤和查询相关时间序列
- **降采样**：支持 avg/sum/min/max/range/count/first/last 聚合，减少历史数据存储
- **集成生态**：原生支持 Prometheus、Grafana

---

## 如何配置 retention（数据保留时间）？

Redis TimeSeries 的 retention 配置有**三级优先级**：

### 1. Key 级别（最高优先级）
创建或修改时间序列时指定：

```sh
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

```sh
TS.ALTER temperature RETENTION 86400000
```

单位：毫秒（60000 = 60 秒）

### 2. 全局默认配置（中优先级）

**Redis < 8.0**（启动时加载）：
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

**Redis >= 8.0**（运行时配置）：
```bash
CONFIG SET ts-retention-policy 25920000000
CONFIG REWRITE  # 持久化到配置文件
```

示例：25920000000 毫秒 = 300 天

### 3. 无保留策略（最低优先级）
如果未设置任何 retention，数据将无限期保留。

### 配置建议
- 对于监控场景，根据数据重要性分级设置（如原始数据 7 天，聚合数据 1 年）
- 结合降采样（downsampling）减少长期存储成本
- 在集群环境中，需在每个节点单独执行 `CONFIG SET`

---

**来源**：
- [Redis TimeSeries Configuration Parameters](../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md) > RETENTION_POLICY 配置示例
- [Redis TimeSeries Use Cases](../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md) > 场景详解
- [RedisTimeSeries 1.0 Release Notes](../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md) > Features 章节

query: Compare Count-Min Sketch and Top-K in Redis probabilistic data structures
answer:
Based on the search results from the Redis documentation, here's a comparison of Count-Min Sketch and Top-K probabilistic data structures:

## Overview

**Count-Min Sketch (CMS)** estimates the frequency of events/elements in a data stream, while **Top-K** identifies the K highest-frequency elements. Both are probabilistic structures that trade perfect accuracy for memory efficiency.

## Key Differences

### Purpose
- **Count-Min Sketch**: Answers "How many times has element X appeared?" for any element you query
- **Top-K**: Answers "What are the K most frequent elements?" and tracks only the top K items

### Data Structure
- **CMS**: Uses a hash table with multiple hash functions (width × depth matrix) to store probabilistic counts
- **Top-K**: Uses two structures in tandem:
  - Hash table for probabilistic counts (similar to CMS)
  - Min heap holding the K items with highest counts

### Algorithm
- **CMS**: Based on the classic Count-Min Sketch algorithm with collision-based over-counting
- **Top-K**: Based on [HeavyKeepers algorithm](https://www.usenix.org/conference/atc18/presentation/gong) with "count-with-exponential-decay" strategy

### Memory & Accuracy Trade-offs
- **CMS**: 
  - Uses sub-linear space
  - Over-counts due to collisions
  - Results below threshold (error_rate × total_count) should be ignored as noise
  - Only useful for higher counts; low counts are unreliable

- **Top-K**:
  - More memory efficient than Sorted Sets for tracking top items
  - Biased against "mouse flows" (small counts), limited impact on "elephant flows" (large counts)
  - Higher accuracy with shorter execution times than previous probabilistic algorithms

### Query Capabilities
- **CMS**: Query frequency of any specific element(s) with `CMS.QUERY`
- **Top-K**: 
  - List all top K items with `TOPK.LIST` (O(K×log(k)))
  - Check if specific item is in top K with `TOPK.QUERY`
  - Get counts for specific items with `TOPK.COUNT`

### Use Cases

**Count-Min Sketch**:
- Product sales volume tracking (retail)
- Any scenario where you need frequency estimates for many different elements
- When you know which elements to query in advance

**Top-K**:
- Trending hashtags on social media
- Network anomaly/DDoS detection (sudden spike in requests)
- Most-read news articles
- When you need to identify the top performers without knowing them in advance

## Overlap & When to Choose

The documentation notes: "There is, indeed, some overlap with the functionality of Count-Min Sketch, but the two data structures have their differences and should be applied for different use cases."

**Choose Count-Min Sketch when**:
- You need to query frequencies of specific known elements
- You're tracking many elements but only care about high-frequency ones
- You can tolerate noise in low-count results

**Choose Top-K when**:
- You need to discover which elements are most frequent (not just count them)
- You want real-time notifications when elements enter/leave the top K
- You need efficient listing of top items without maintaining a full Sorted Set

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/count-min-sketch.md > Examples]
[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/top-k.md > Use case]

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_6H38NlOGwXzEtHshdbMEhN', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 4.5828,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"5f323784\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"5f323784-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/count-min-sketch.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Count-min sketch\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Examples\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Count-Min Sketch is a probabilistic data structure in Redis Open Source that can be used to estimate the frequency of events/elements in a stream of data.\\\\n\\\\nIt uses a sub-linear space at the expense of over-counting some events due to collisions. It consumes a stream of events/elements and keeps estimated counters of their frequency.\\\\n\\\\nIt is very important to know that the results coming from a Count-Min sketch lower than a certain threshold (determined by the error_rate) should be ignored and often even approximated to zero. So Count-Min sketch is indeed a data-structure for counting frequencies of elements in a stream, but it\'s only useful for higher counts. Very low counts should be ignored as noise.\\\\n\\\\n**Products (retail, online shops)** \\\\n\\\\nThis application answers this question: What was the sales volume (on a certain day) for a product? \\\\n\\\\nUse one Count-Min sketch created per day (period). Every product sale goes into the CMS. The CMS give reasonably accurate results for the products that contribute the most toward the sales. Products with low percentage of the total sales are ignored.\\\\n\\\\nAssume you select an error rate of 0.1% (0.001) with a certainty of 99.8% (0.998). This means you have an error probability of 0.02% (0.002). Your sketch strives to keep the error within 0.1% of the total count of all elements you\'ve added. There\'s a 0.02% chance the error might exceed this—like when an element below the threshold overlaps with one above it. When you add a few items to the CMS and evaluate their frequency, remember that in such a small sample, collisions are rare, as seen with other probabilistic data structures.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> CMS.INITBYPROB bikes:profit 0.001 0.002\\\\nOK\\\\n> CMS.INCRBY bikes:profit \\\\\\"Smokey Mountain Striker\\\\\\" 100\\\\n(integer) 100\\\\n> CMS.INCRBY bikes:profit \\\\\\"Rocky Mountain Racer\\\\\\" 200 \\\\\\"Cloudy City Cruiser\\\\\\" 150\\\\n1) (integer) 200\\\\n2) (integer) 150\\\\n> CMS.QUERY bikes:profit \\\\\\"Smokey Mountain Striker\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Rocky Mountain Racer\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Cloudy City Cruiser\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Terrible Bike Name\\\\\\"\\\\n1) (integer) 100\\\\n2) (integer) 200\\\\n3) (integer) 150\\\\n4) (integer) 0\\\\n> CMS.INFO bikes:profit\\\\n1) width\\\\n2) (integer) 2000\\\\n3) depth\\\\n4) (integer) 9\\\\n5) count\\\\n6) (integer) 450\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 4.4218,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"73073dca\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"73073dca-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/top-k.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Top-K\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Use case\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Top K is a probabilistic data structure in Redis Open Source used to estimate the `K` highest-rank elements from a stream.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\"Highest-rank\\\\\\" in this case means \\\\\\"elements with a highest number or score attached to them\\\\\\", where the score can be a count of how many times the element has appeared in the stream - thus making the data structure perfect for finding the elements with the highest frequency in a stream.\\\\nOne very common application is detecting network anomalies and DDoS attacks where Top K can answer the question: Is there a sudden increase in the flux of requests to the same address or from the same IP?\\\\n \\\\nThere is, indeed, some overlap with the functionality of Count-Min Sketch, but the two data structures have their differences and should be applied for different use cases. \\\\n\\\\nThe Redis Open Source implementation of Top-K is based on the [HeavyKeepers](https://www.usenix.org/conference/atc18/presentation/gong) algorithm presented by Junzhi Gong et al. It discards some older approaches like \\\\\\"count-all\\\\\\" and \\\\\\"admit-all-count-some\\\\\\" in favour of a \\\\\\"**count-with-exponential-decay**\\\\\\" strategy which is biased against mouse (small) flows and has a limited impact on elephant (large) flows. This implementation uses two data structures in tandem: a hash table that holds the probabilistic counts (much like the Count-Min Sketch), and a min heap that holds the `K` items with the highest counts. This ensures high accuracy with shorter execution times than previous probabilistic algorithms allowed, while keeping memory utilization to a fraction of what is typically required by a Sorted Set. It has the additional benefit of being able to get real time notifications when elements are added or removed from the Top K list.\\\\n\\\\n**Trending hashtags (social media platforms, news distribution networks)** \\\\n\\\\nThis application answers these questions: \\\\n\\\\n- What are the K hashtags people have mentioned the most in the last X hours? \\\\n- What are the K news with highest read/view count today? \\\\n\\\\nData flow is the incoming social media posts from which you parse out the different hashtags. \\\\n\\\\nThe [`TOPK.LIST`]() command has a time complexity of `O(K*log(k))` so if `K` is small, there is no need to keep a separate set or sorted set of all the hashtags. You can query directly from the Top K itself.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.8697,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"49a1af21\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"49a1af21-011\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisce/redisos-8.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisos 8.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Open Source 8.0.0 (May 2025) > Security fixes (compared to 8.0-RC1)\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"- Name change: Redis Community Edition is now Redis Open Source\\\\n- License change: licensed under your choice of \\\\n  - (a) the Redis Source Available License 2.0 (RSALv2); or\\\\n  - (b) the Server Side Public License v1 (SSPLv1); or\\\\n  - (c) the GNU Affero General Public License (AGPLv3)\\\\n- Redis Query Engine and 8 new data structures are now an integral part of Redis 8.\\\\n  - (1) Redis Query Engine, which now supports both horizontal and vertical scaling for search, query, and vector workloads.\\\\n  - (2) JSON, a queryable JSON document data type.\\\\n  - (3) Time series.\\\\n  - (4-8) Five probabilistic data structures: Bloom filter, Cuckoo filter, Count-min sketch, Top-k, and t-digest.\\\\n  - (9) Vector set [preview], a data structure designed for vector similarity search, inspired by sorted set.\\\\n  - These nine components are included in all binary distributions.\\\\n\\\\n  - See the [build instructions]() for information about building from source code.\\\\n  - New configuration file: `redis-full.conf`, loads Redis with all components, \\\\n    and contains new configuration parameters for Redis Query Engine and the new data structures.\\\\n  - New ACL categories: `@search`, `@json`, `@timeseries`, `@bloom`, `@cuckoo`, `@cms`, `@topk`, and `@tdigest` commands are also included in the existing ACL categories such as `@read` and `@write`. See [below]() for information about potentially breaking changes.\\\\n- More than 30 performance and resource utilization improvements.\\\\n- A new I/O threading implementation, which enables throughput increase on multi-core environments\\\\n  (set with the `io-threads` configuration parameter).\\\\n- An improved replication mechanism that is more performant and robust.\\\\n- New hash commands: [HGETDEL](), [HGETEX](), and [HSETEX]()\\\\n\\\\nFor more details, see the release notes for the [8.0-M01](https://github.com/redis/redis/releases/tag/8.0-m01), 9.5.\\\\n- Debian 11 (Bullseye) and 12 (Bookworm).\\\\n- macOS 13 (Ventura), 14 (Sonoma), and 15 (Sequoia).\\\\n\\\\n- From previous Redis versions without modules.\\\\n- From previous Redis versions with modules (RediSearch, RedisJSON, RedisTimeSeries, RedisBloom).\\\\n- From Redis Stack 7.2 or 7.4.\\\\n\\\\n* (CVE-2025-21605) An unauthenticated client can cause an unlimited growth of output buffers\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.7832,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"5f323784\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"5f323784-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/count-min-sketch.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Count-min sketch\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Sizing > 2. Probability\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"The `error` parameter will determine the width `w` of your sketch and the probability will determine the number of hash functions (depth `d`). The error rate we choose will determine the threshold above which we can trust the result from the sketch. The correlation is:\\\\n```\\\\nthreshold = error * total_count \\\\n```\\\\nor\\\\n```\\\\nerror = threshold/total_count\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nwhere `total_count` is the sum of the count of all elements that can be obtained from the `count` key of the result of the [`CMS.INFO`]() command and is of course dynamic - it changes with every new increment in the sketch. At creation time you can approximate the `total_count` ratio as a product of the average count you\'ll be expecting in the sketch and the average number of elements.\\\\n\\\\nSince the threshold is a function of the total count in the filter it\'s very important to note that it will grow as  the count grows, but knowing the total count we can always dynamically calculate the threshold. If a result is below it - it can be discarded.\\\\n\\\\n`probability` in this data structure represents the chance of an element that has a count below the threshold to collide with elements that had a count above the threshold on all sketches/depths thus returning a min-count of a frequently occurring element instead of its own.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.4071,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"ede072de\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"ede072de-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisbloom/redisbloom-2.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisbloom 2.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v2.0.0 (June 2019)\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"RedisBloom v2.0.3 requires:\\\\n\\\\n- Minimum Redis compatibility version (database): 4.0.0\\\\n- Minimum Redis Enterprise Software version (cluster): 5.0.0\\\\n\\\\n- Performance improvements:\\\\n    - #[95](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/issues/95) Top-K - Reduce checks on heap, now only checks if item count is larger than minimum in heap.\\\\n    - #[95](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/issues/95) Top-K - The power of decay was calculated every time. Changed to use a lookup table.\\\\n- Major bug fix:\\\\n    - #[88](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/issues/88) Replication available for newly added Top-K and Count-min sketch\\\\n- Minor bug fixes:\\\\n    - #[89](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/issues/89) Module update broke rdb files\\\\n    - #[98](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/issues/98) Compilation for macOS\\\\n\\\\nWe are proud to announce that we doubled the number of probabilistic data structures that are generally available in RedisBloom.  Full documentation is available on [redisbloom.io](https://redisbloom.io)\\\\n\\\\n- #[70](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/issues/70) Top-K\\\\n    - [Commands]()\\\\n    - [Algorithm](https://www.usenix.org/conference/atc18/presentation/gong)\\\\n\\\\n- #[65](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/issues/65) Count-min Sketch\\\\n    - [Commands]()\\\\n    - [Algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Count%E2%80%93min_sketch)\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.1573,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"0904b4cf\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"0904b4cf-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/get-started/redis-in-ai.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis In Ai\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Use Cases in GenAI Apps\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis enables high-performance, scalable, and reliable data management, making it a key component for GenAI apps, chatbots, and AI agents. By leveraging Redis for fast data retrieval, caching, and vector search capabilities, you can enhance AI-powered interactions, reduce latency, and improve user experience.\\\\n\\\\nRedis excels in storing and indexing vector embeddings that semantically represent unstructured data. With vector search, Redis retrieves similar questions and relevant data, lowering LLM inference costs and latency. It fetches pertinent portions of chat history, enriching context for more accurate and relevant responses. These features make Redis an ideal choice for RAG systems and GenAI apps requiring fast data access.\\\\n\\\\n- **Performance**: low-latency data access enables real-time interactions critical for AI-driven applications.\\\\n- **Scalability**: designed to handle numerous concurrent connections, Redis is perfect for high-demand GenAI apps.\\\\n- **Caching**: efficiently stores frequently accessed data and responses, reducing primary database load and accelerating response times.\\\\n- **Session Management**: in-memory data structures simplify managing session states in conversational AI scenarios.\\\\n- **Flexibility**: Redis supports diverse data structures (for example, strings, hashes, lists, sets), allowing tailored solutions for GenAI apps.\\\\n\\\\n[RedisVL]() is a Python library with an integrated CLI, offering seamless integration with Redis to enhance GenAI applications.\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\nExplore how Redis optimizes various GenAI applications through specific use cases, tutorials, and demo code repositories.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.9834,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"40893428\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"40893428-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-7.4-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisstack 7.4 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Community Edition 7.4.0-v0 (July 2024) > Headlines\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"**Data Structures**\\\\n\\\\n`Hash`: Redis now supports expiration of individual hash fields. Redis already supports key expiration. For each key, users can specify a time when it should expire, or specify the remaining time-to-live (TTL) after which it would expire. One very frequent request was to allow specifying expiration time or TTL also for individual hash fields, which is now supported using nine new Redis commands:\\\\n- `HEXPIRE`, `HPEXPIRE`, `HEXPIREAT`, `HPEXPIREAT` - set the time when specific hash fields should expire, or the remaining time-to-live for specific fields. \\\\n- `HTTL`, `HPTTL`, `HEXPIRETIME`, `HPEXPIRETIME` - retrieve the time when specific hash fields should expire, or the remaining time-to-live for specific fields\\\\n- `HPERSIST` - remove the expiration of specific hash fields.\\\\n\\\\n`Streams`: It is now possible to start reading from the last stream message using `XREAD` with the new id value `+`.\\\\nThere are many additional improvements, including new command arguments, security, performance, and resource utilization enhancements, several new metrics and configuration parameters were introduced, and multiple bugs were fixed.\\\\n\\\\n`Time series`: The latest time series data structure adds a highly requested feature: insertion-filter for close samples. Many sensors report data periodically. Often, the difference between the measured value and the previously measured value is negligible and related to random noise or to measurement accuracy limitations. When both the time difference and the value difference between the current and the previous sample are small, it may be preferable to ignore (not to add) the new measurement.\\\\n\\\\n`JSON`: Introduces a fix to avoid duplicating AOF commands multiple times in `JSON.MSET`.\\\\n\\\\n`Probabilistic`: Now, an error is returned if `CMS.MERGE` results in an overflow or underflow.\\\\n\\\\n**Search and query**\\\\n\\\\n- New `BFLOAT16` and `FLOAT16` vector data types reduce memory consumed by vectors while preserving accuracy.\\\\n- Support for indexing empty and missing values and enhanced developer experience for queries with exact matching capabilities.\\\\n- Developers can now match `TAG` fields without needing to escape special characters, making the onboarding process and use of the query syntax simpler.\\\\n- Geospatial search capabilities have been expanded with new `INTERSECT` and `DISJOINT` operators, and ergonomics have been improved by providing better reporting of the memory consumed by the index and exposing the Full-text scoring in the aggregation pipeline.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nIf one or more fields of a hash key expire after a query begins (using FT.SEARCH or FT.AGGREGATE), Redis does not account for these lazily expired fields. As a result, keys with expired fields may still be included in the query results, leading to potentially incorrect or inconsistent results.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Removal of triggers and functions**\\\\n\\\\nRedis Stack 7.4 will no longer include triggers and functions. To ensure a seamless upgrade, remove any T&F functions created before loading an RDB file into the new Redis Stack.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.8654,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"42579dc8\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"42579dc8-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/hyperloglogs.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"HyperLogLog\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Use cases\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"HyperLogLog is a probabilistic data structure that estimates the cardinality of a set, trading perfect accuracy for efficient space utilization. The Redis implementation uses up to 12 KB of memory and provides a standard error rate of 0.81%.\\\\n\\\\nCounting unique items usually requires an amount of memory\\\\nproportional to the number of items you want to count, because you need\\\\nto remember the elements you have already seen in the past in order to avoid\\\\ncounting them multiple times. However, a set of algorithms exist that trade \\\\nmemory for precision: they return an estimated measure with a standard error, \\\\nwhich, in the case of the Redis implementation for HyperLogLog, is less than 1%.\\\\nThe magic of this algorithm is that you no longer need to use an amount of memory\\\\nproportional to the number of items counted, and instead can use a\\\\nconstant amount of memory; 12k bytes in the worst case, or a lot less if your\\\\nHyperLogLog (We\'ll just call them HLL from now) has seen very few elements.\\\\n\\\\nHLLs in Redis, while technically a different data structure, are encoded\\\\nas a Redis string, so you can call [`GET`]() to serialize a HLL, and [`SET`]()\\\\nto deserialize it back to the server.\\\\n\\\\nConceptually the HLL API is like using Sets to do the same task. You would\\\\n[`SADD`]() every observed element into a set, and would use [`SCARD`]() to check the\\\\nnumber of elements inside the set, which are unique since [`SADD`]() will not\\\\nre-add an existing element.\\\\n\\\\nWhile you don\'t really *add items* into an HLL, because the data structure\\\\nonly contains a state that does not include actual elements, the API is the\\\\nsame:\\\\n\\\\n* Every time you see a new element, you add it to the count with [`PFADD`]().\\\\n* When you want to retrieve the current approximation of unique elements added using the [`PFADD`]() command, you can use the [`PFCOUNT`]() command. If you need to merge two different HLLs, the [`PFMERGE`]() command is available. Since HLLs provide approximate counts of unique elements, the result of the merge will give you an approximation of the number of unique elements across both source HLLs.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> PFADD bikes Hyperion Deimos Phoebe Quaoar\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> PFCOUNT bikes\\\\n(integer) 4\\\\n> PFADD commuter_bikes Salacia Mimas Quaoar\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> PFMERGE all_bikes bikes commuter_bikes\\\\nOK\\\\n> PFCOUNT all_bikes\\\\n(integer) 6\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nSome examples of use cases for this data structure is counting unique queries\\\\nperformed by users in a search form every day, number of unique visitors to a web page and other similar cases.\\\\n\\\\nRedis is also able to perform the union of HLLs, please check the\\\\n[full documentation]() for more information.\\\\n\\\\n**Anonymous unique visits of a web page (SaaS, analytics tools)** \\\\n\\\\nThis application answers these questions: \\\\n\\\\n- How many unique visits has this page had on this day? \\\\n- How many unique users have played this song? \\\\n- How many unique users have viewed this video? \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n \\\\nStoring the IP address or any other kind of personal identifier is against the law in some countries, which makes it impossible to get unique visitor statistics on your website.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nOne HyperLogLog is created per page (video/song) per period, and every IP/identifier is added to it on every visit.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.6159,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"d42c8ffb\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"d42c8ffb-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": [TextBlock(text='Based on the search results from the Redis documentation, here's a comparison of Count-Min Sketch and Top-K probabilistic data structures:

## Overview

**Count-Min Sketch (CMS)** estimates the frequency of events/elements in a data stream, while **Top-K** identifies the K highest-frequency elements. Both are probabilistic structures that trade perfect accuracy for memory efficiency.

## Key Differences

### Purpose
- **Count-Min Sketch**: Answers "How many times has element X appeared?" for any element you query
- **Top-K**: Answers "What are the K most frequent elements?" and tracks only the top K items

### Data Structure
- **CMS**: Uses a hash table with multiple hash functions (width × depth matrix) to store probabilistic counts
- **Top-K**: Uses two structures in tandem:
  - Hash table for probabilistic counts (similar to CMS)
  - Min heap holding the K items with highest counts

### Algorithm
- **CMS**: Based on the classic Count-Min Sketch algorithm with collision-based over-counting
- **Top-K**: Based on [HeavyKeepers algorithm](https://www.usenix.org/conference/atc18/presentation/gong) with "count-with-exponential-decay" strategy

### Memory & Accuracy Trade-offs
- **CMS**: 
  - Uses sub-linear space
  - Over-counts due to collisions
  - Results below threshold (error_rate × total_count) should be ignored as noise
  - Only useful for higher counts; low counts are unreliable

- **Top-K**:
  - More memory efficient than Sorted Sets for tracking top items
  - Biased against "mouse flows" (small counts), limited impact on "elephant flows" (large counts)
  - Higher accuracy with shorter execution times than previous probabilistic algorithms

### Query Capabilities
- **CMS**: Query frequency of any specific element(s) with `CMS.QUERY`
- **Top-K**: 
  - List all top K items with `TOPK.LIST` (O(K×log(k)))
  - Check if specific item is in top K with `TOPK.QUERY`
  - Get counts for specific items with `TOPK.COUNT`

### Use Cases

**Count-Min Sketch**:
- Product sales volume tracking (retail)
- Any scenario where you need frequency estimates for many different elements
- When you know which elements to query in advance

**Top-K**:
- Trending hashtags on social media
- Network anomaly/DDoS detection (sudden spike in requests)
- Most-read news articles
- When you need to identify the top performers without knowing them in advance

## Overlap & When to Choose

The documentation notes: "There is, indeed, some overlap with the functionality of Count-Min Sketch, but the two data structures have their differences and should be applied for different use cases."

**Choose Count-Min Sketch when**:
- You need to query frequencies of specific known elements
- You're tracking many elements but only care about high-frequency ones
- You can tolerate noise in low-count results

**Choose Top-K when**:
- You need to discover which elements are most frequent (not just count them)
- You want real-time notifications when elements enter/leave the top K
- You need efficient listing of top items without maintaining a full Sorted Set

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/count-min-sketch.md > Examples]
[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/top-k.md > Use case]')]

query: How does Redis Sentinel handle automatic failover?
answer:
Redis Sentinel handles automatic failover through a distributed consensus mechanism. Here's how it works:

## Failover Detection

**Two-stage failure detection:**
- **SDOWN (Subjectively Down)**: A single Sentinel marks the master as down when it doesn't receive valid PING replies for the configured timeout period (`down-after-milliseconds`)
- **ODOWN (Objectively Down)**: Multiple Sentinels (at least the configured `quorum`) agree the master is down through gossip protocol using `SENTINEL is-master-down-by-addr` commands

Only when ODOWN state is reached can a failover be triggered.

## Failover Process

1. **Authorization**: A Sentinel must receive authorization from the majority of known Sentinels before starting failover

2. **Replica Selection**: The system evaluates replicas based on:
   - Disconnection time from master (replicas disconnected > 10x timeout are skipped)
   - `replica-priority` (lower is preferred)
   - Replication offset (replica with most data wins)
   - Run ID (lexicographically smaller, for determinism)

3. **Promotion**: The selected replica receives `REPLICAOF NO ONE` command to become the new master

4. **Configuration Propagation**: Once the switch is confirmed via `INFO` output, the new configuration (with incremented version number) is broadcast via `__sentinel__:hello` Pub/Sub channel

5. **Reconfiguration**: Other replicas are reconfigured to replicate from the new master. All Sentinels converge to the highest version number configuration.

## Key Properties

- **Distributed system**: Multiple Sentinels cooperate to reduce false positives and eliminate single points of failure
- **Service discovery**: Clients connect to Sentinels to discover the current master address
- **Self-healing**: Failed masters are automatically reconfigured as replicas when they return

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/sentinel.md > Sentinel as a distributed system, SDOWN and ODOWN failure state, Replica selection and priority, Configuration propagation]
